This differs from hydrodynamic pumps (e.g., centrifugal pumps) where energy is added to the fluid by an impeller, increasing its velocity and pressure. In hydrodynamic pumps, flow can vary greatly with pressure, and there is no positive internal sealing against backflow. Positive displacement pumps, on the other hand, provide a relatively constant flow rate regardless of the pressure (within their design limits) making them suitable for applications requiring precise flow control.

Positive displacement pumps have several advantages: They can generate high pressures, have relatively small sizes, and have high volumetric efficiency, and the change in efficiency is relatively small. However, they also have disadvantages such as complex moving parts and higher initial cost.

Gear pumps use rotating gears to trap and displace fluid. Vane pumps use sliding vanes within a rotor to create chambers that transport fluid. Piston pumps use reciprocating pistons within cylinders to displace fluid.

Mathematical Relationships:

The volumetric displacement (\(V_d\)) of a positive displacement pump is the volume of fluid displaced per revolution of the pump’s rotating element.

The theoretical flow rate (\(Q_{th}\)) is:\(Q_{th} = V_d \cdot N\)where\(N\)is the pump speed (revolutions per unit time).

The volumetric efficiency (\(\eta_v\)) is:\(\eta_v = \frac{Q_{act}}{Q_{th}}\)Volumetric losses can be caused by leakage, internal slip, etc.

Overall efficiency (\(\eta_o\)):\(\eta_o = \eta_v \cdot \eta_{mh}\)Where\(\eta_{mh}\)is the mechanical-hydraulic efficiency

[Image generation failed for: Simplified animation frames illustrating the operation of an external gear pump. Two gears mesh, trapping fluid in the spaces between the teeth and conveying it from the suction to the discharge port.]

[Image generation failed for: Cross-sectional view of a balanced vane pump showing the rotor, vanes, cam ring, and pressure ports. Include arrows to indicate the direction of fluid flow and the direction of rotation.]

[Image generation failed for: Cutaway view of an axial piston pump illustrating the pistons, cylinder block, swash plate, and valve plate. Show how the reciprocating motion of the pistons is converted into a continuous flow.]

Example Problem 1: Calculating Pump Flow Rate

A gear pump has a volumetric displacement of\(10 \text{ cm}^3/\text{rev}\)and is driven at a speed of 1500 rpm. Calculate the theoretical flow rate.

Given: * Volumetric displacement,\(V_d = 10 \text{ cm}^3/\text{rev} = 10 \times 10^{-6} \text{ m}^3/\text{rev}\)* Pump speed,\(N = 1500 \text{ rpm} = \frac{1500}{60} \text{ rev/s} = 25 \text{ rev/s}\)Solution: 1. Calculate the theoretical flow rate:\(Q_{th} = V_d \cdot N = (10 \times 10^{-6}) \times 25 = 0.00025 \text{ m}^3/\text{s} = 15 \text{ lpm}\)Example Problem 2: Determining Volumetric Efficiency

A piston pump has a volumetric displacement of\(20 \text{ cm}^3/\text{rev}\)and is driven at a speed of 2000 rpm. The actual flow rate is measured to be 40 lpm. Calculate the volumetric efficiency.

Given: * Volumetric displacement,\(V_d = 20 \text{ cm}^3/\text{rev} = 20 \times 10^{-6} \text{ m}^3/\text{rev}\)* Pump speed,\(N = 2000 \text{ rpm} = \frac{2000}{60} \text{ rev/s} = 33.33 \text{ rev/s}\)* Actual flow rate,\(Q_{act} = 40 \text{ lpm} = 0.000667 \text{ m}^3/\text{s}\)Solution: 1. Calculate the theoretical flow rate:$Q_{th} = V_d N = (20 ^{-6}) = 0.000667 ^3/ = 40 \(2. Calculate the volumetric efficiency:\)_v = = = 1 = 100%$—

1.1 Introduction to Hydrodynamic Pumps (Non-Positive Displacement)

1.1.1 Theoretical Introduction

Hydrodynamic pumps, also known as non-positive displacement pumps, operate on a fundamentally different principle compared to positive displacement pumps. The key distinction lies in how they generate flow and how their flow rate responds to changes in system pressure (or load). In positive displacement pumps, a fixed volume of fluid is mechanically displaced with each cycle of the pump, leading to a relatively constant flow rate regardless of the downstream pressure, until the structural limits of the pump are reached. Hydrodynamic pumps, on the other hand, rely on imparting kinetic energy to the fluid, which is then converted into pressure. Crucially, they do not have a tight internal seal to prevent backflow or “slip.”

This internal leakage, or clearance, is the defining characteristic of hydrodynamic pumps. The amount of fluid that slips back through these clearances increases as the downstream pressure increases. This is because the pressure difference between the outlet and inlet drives fluid back through the clearances. Because the fluid can easily leak backwards through the pump, the flow rate of a hydrodynamic pump is very sensitive to the pressure on the output side of the pump. A “positive sealing” pump would have almost no back-leakage, and the flow rate would be nearly independent of output pressure. This difference means that hydrodynamic pumps are not suited for all applications.

The advantages of hydrodynamic pumps stem from their design. They provide a smooth, continuous flow (when a demand exists), which is beneficial in applications where pulsating flow is undesirable. Furthermore, hydrodynamic pumps, particularly centrifugal pumps, can handle variable demand exceptionally well. This characteristic makes them suitable for applications where the required flow rate fluctuates significantly over time, such as in municipal water supply systems. A key disadvantage of these pumps is the sensitivity of their flow rate to the load. If the outlet is blocked, the flow drops to zero.

One important concept related to hydrodynamic pumps is the “shutoff head.” The shutoff head is the maximum pressure the pump can generate when there is no flow (i.e., the outlet is completely blocked). This pressure corresponds to the maximum energy that the pump can impart to the fluid under those conditions. The shutoff head represents the point where all the energy input into the pump is used to overcome internal losses and maintain pressure, rather than producing flow.

Hydrodynamic pumps are often preferred in applications where high flow rates are required at relatively low pressures, and where the demand for fluid is variable. For example, in municipal water supply, centrifugal pumps are used to deliver water to homes and businesses. The demand for water varies throughout the day, and centrifugal pumps can readily handle these changes in demand without requiring complex control systems. In contrast, using positive displacement pumps in high-volume applications can lead to issues with fluid inertia and pressure spikes when flow is suddenly stopped or started. The compliance provided by the internal leakage of a hydrodynamic pump is a benefit in such situations.

From a first-principles perspective, the operation of a hydrodynamic pump can be understood by applying the principles of conservation of mass (continuity equation) and Bernoulli’s principle for incompressible flow. The continuity equation states that for an incompressible fluid, the mass flow rate must remain constant throughout the pump. Bernoulli’s principle, in a simplified form, relates the pressure, velocity, and height of a fluid along a streamline. These principles help explain how the pump converts mechanical energy into fluid kinetic energy and pressure.

1.1.2 Mathematical Derivations

A simplified “slip” flow model can be used to describe the behavior of hydrodynamic pumps. The actual flow rate Q is the difference between the ideal flow rate Q_ideal (based on impeller geometry and speed) and the slip flow rate Q_slip (the leakage flow).\(Q = Q_{ideal} - Q_{slip}\)The slip flow Q_slip can be modeled as proportional to the pressure difference across the pump (p_outlet - p_inlet) and inversely proportional to a “slip resistance” term R_slip. This slip resistance represents the resistance to flow through the clearances within the pump.\(Q_{slip} = \frac{p_{outlet} - p_{inlet}}{R_{slip}}\)Volumetric efficiency η_v is defined as the ratio of the actual flow rate to the ideal flow rate:\(\eta_v = \frac{Q}{Q_{ideal}}\)Substituting the expression for Q and Q_slip:\(\eta_v = \frac{Q_{ideal} - Q_{slip}}{Q_{ideal}} = 1 - \frac{Q_{slip}}{Q_{ideal}}\)Therefore, the volumetric efficiency can be expressed in terms of the pressure difference and slip resistance:\(\eta_v = 1 - \frac{p_{outlet} - p_{inlet}}{R_{slip} Q_{ideal}}\)The ideal flow rate Q_ideal can be related to impeller geometry and rotational speed. Assuming a constant fluid density, the ideal flow rate can be approximated as:\(Q_{ideal} = A \cdot v = (2 \pi r w) \cdot (r \omega \tan{\beta})\)where r is the impeller radius, w is the impeller width, β is the blade angle, and ω is angular velocity.\(A\)is the effective flow area and\(v\)is the fluid velocity.

A simplified expression for the pump head (pressure rise) can be derived from the Euler turbomachine equation. For a centrifugal pump, assuming that the inlet swirl is negligible, the pump head can be approximated as:\(H = \frac{v_2^2 - v_1^2}{2g} = \frac{(r_2 \omega)^2 - (r_1 \omega)^2}{2g}\)where r1 and r2 are inlet and outlet impeller radii, respectively, ω is angular velocity, and g is gravitational acceleration.

The pressure rise across the pump is then:\(p_{outlet} - p_{inlet} = \rho g H\)where ρ is fluid density and g is gravitational acceleration.

[Image generation failed for: Cross-sectional view of a generic centrifugal pump showing the impeller, volute, inlet, and outlet. Arrows indicating flow direction.]

1.1.3 Mirror Problems

  • Problem 1: A centrifugal pump delivers water. The impeller radius is 100 mm, the width is 10 mm, the blade angle is 30 degrees, the rotational speed is 2000 RPM, and the slip resistance is 5e7 Pa.s/m^3. Calculate the actual flow rate and volumetric efficiency at outlet pressures of 100 kPa, 500 kPa, and 1 MPa, assuming the inlet pressure is 0 Pa gauge.

    • Solution:

      1. Convert RPM to angular velocity:$= 2000 \(2. Calculate the ideal flow rate:\)Q_{ideal} = (2 r w) (r ) = (2 ) (0.1 ) ^3/$3. Calculate the slip flow rate for each outlet pressure:

        • At\(p_{outlet} = 100 \text{ kPa}\):\(Q_{slip} = \frac{100,000}{5 \times 10^7} = 0.002 \text{ m}^3/\text{s}\)* At\(p_{outlet} = 500 \text{ kPa}\):\(Q_{slip} = \frac{500,000}{5 \times 10^7} = 0.01 \text{ m}^3/\text{s}\)* At\(p_{outlet} = 1 \text{ MPa}\):$Q_{slip} = = 0.02 ^3/$4. Calculate the actual flow rate for each outlet pressure:

        • At\(p_{outlet} = 100 \text{ kPa}\):\(Q = 0.76 - 0.002 = 0.758 \text{ m}^3/\text{s}\)* At\(p_{outlet} = 500 \text{ kPa}\):\(Q = 0.76 - 0.01 = 0.75 \text{ m}^3/\text{s}\)* At\(p_{outlet} = 1 \text{ MPa}\):$Q = 0.76 - 0.02 = 0.74 ^3/$5. Calculate the volumetric efficiency for each outlet pressure:

        • At\(p_{outlet} = 100 \text{ kPa}\):\(\eta_v = \frac{0.758}{0.76} \approx 0.997\)or 99.7%

        • At\(p_{outlet} = 500 \text{ kPa}\):\(\eta_v = \frac{0.75}{0.76} \approx 0.987\)or 98.7%

        • At\(p_{outlet} = 1 \text{ MPa}\):\(\eta_v = \frac{0.74}{0.76} \approx 0.974\)or 97.4%

  • Problem 2: A centrifugal pump has an ideal flow rate of 0.1 m^3/s. At a pressure difference of 2 MPa, the actual flow rate is 0.08 m^3/s. Determine the slip resistance and the power lost due to slip.

    • Solution:
      1. Calculate the slip flow rate:$Q_{slip} = Q_{ideal} - Q = 0.1 - 0.08 = 0.02 ^3/\(2. Calculate the slip resistance:\)R_{slip} = = = 1 ^8 ^3\(3. Calculate the power lost due to slip:\){slip} = Q{slip} (p_{outlet} - p_{inlet}) = 0.02 (2 ^6) = 40,000 $or 40 kW.

[Image generation failed for: Schematic of a slip flow model, showing ideal flow, slip flow, and the pressure difference driving the slip.]

1.2 Centrifugal Pump Operation and Characteristics

1.2.1 Theoretical Introduction

The operation of a centrifugal pump relies on the principle of converting mechanical energy into kinetic energy and subsequently into pressure energy. The rotating impeller, with its curved blades, imparts angular momentum to the fluid as it enters the pump near the center (the “eye” of the impeller). The centrifugal force generated by the rotation forces the fluid to move radially outward, increasing its velocity. As the fluid exits the impeller, it enters the volute, a spiral-shaped casing that gradually increases in cross-sectional area. This increase in area causes the fluid velocity to decrease, converting the kinetic energy into pressure energy.

The angle of the impeller blades has a significant impact on the pump’s performance characteristics. There are three primary types of blade configurations: forward-curved, radial, and backward-curved. Forward-curved blades produce the highest head at a given flow rate, but they are also more prone to instability and surging. Radial blades offer a compromise between head and flow rate. Backward-curved blades provide a stable and efficient operation over a wide range of flow rates, making them the most common choice for many applications. The slope of the head vs. flow characteristic curve is different for each of these cases.

Cavitation is a phenomenon that can occur in centrifugal pumps when the local pressure drops below the vapor pressure of the liquid. This causes the liquid to vaporize, forming bubbles that are carried along with the fluid flow. As these bubbles enter regions of higher pressure, they collapse violently, generating shock waves that can damage the impeller and volute. Cavitation is primarily caused by low inlet pressure, high fluid temperature (which increases vapor pressure), or excessive flow rates.

Net Positive Suction Head (NPSH) is a critical parameter in pump selection and operation. It represents the absolute pressure at the suction side of the pump, above the vapor pressure of the liquid. NPSH is the pressure available to prevent cavitation. There is the “available” NPSH (NPSHA), which is a property of the system in which the pump is installed, and there is the “required” NPSH (NPSHR), which is a property of the pump itself. For reliable pump operation, the NPSHA must always be greater than the NPSHR.

Axial flow pumps, also known as propeller pumps, are another type of hydrodynamic pump. Unlike centrifugal pumps, which discharge fluid radially, axial flow pumps discharge fluid in an axial direction, parallel to the pump’s axis of rotation. Axial flow pumps are typically used for applications requiring very high flow rates at low heads, such as irrigation and flood control.

From a first-principles perspective, the operation of a centrifugal pump involves the application of conservation of angular momentum. The impeller imparts angular momentum to the fluid, increasing its tangential velocity. The change in angular momentum is directly related to the torque exerted by the impeller on the fluid. Additionally, understanding vapor pressure and the cavitation number is crucial for preventing cavitation and ensuring reliable pump operation.

1.2.2 Mathematical Derivations

The theoretical head developed by a centrifugal pump can be calculated using the Euler turbomachine equation:\(H = \frac{v_{u2} r_2 - v_{u1} r_1}{g}\)where\(v_u\)is the tangential component of the absolute velocity at the inlet (1) and outlet (2), r is radius, and g is gravitational acceleration.

The tangential velocity components can be expressed in terms of the blade speed (u = rω) and the radial component of velocity (v_r) and the blade angle (β):\(v_{u2} = u_2 - v_{r2} \cot{\beta_2}\)and\(v_{u1} = u_1 - v_{r1} \cot{\beta_1}\)Substituting these expressions into the Euler turbomachine equation:\(H = \frac{(u_2 - v_{r2} \cot{\beta_2}) r_2 - (u_1 - v_{r1} \cot{\beta_1}) r_1}{g}\)The Net Positive Suction Head Available (NPSHA) is defined as:\(NPSHA = \frac{p_{inlet}}{\rho g} + \frac{v_{inlet}^2}{2g} - \frac{p_{vapor}}{\rho g}\)where p_inlet is inlet pressure, v_inlet is inlet velocity, and p_vapor is the vapor pressure of the fluid.

The cavitation number is a dimensionless parameter that relates NPSHA to the total head developed by the pump:\(\sigma = \frac{NPSHA}{H}\)The hydraulic power delivered by the pump is:\(\mathcal{P}_{hyd} = Q \cdot (p_{outlet} - p_{inlet})\)The input power required to drive the pump is:\(\mathcal{P}_{in} = \frac{\mathcal{P}_{hyd}}{\eta_{hyd}}\)where\(\eta_{hyd}\)is the hydraulic efficiency.

[Image generation failed for: Impeller geometry showing forward-curved, radial, and backward-curved blades. Label blade angle β.]

1.2.3 Mirror Problems

  • Problem 1: A centrifugal pump has backward-curved blades with an outlet angle of 25 degrees. The outlet diameter is 250 mm, and the pump rotates at 1750 RPM. The flow rate is 0.06 m^3/s. The inlet is radial, so v_u1 = 0. Determine the theoretical head developed by the pump.

    • Solution:
      1. Calculate the outlet radius:$r_2 = = 0.125 \(2. Convert RPM to angular velocity:\)= 1750 \(3. Calculate the blade speed at the outlet:\)u_2 = r_2 = 0.125 \(4. Calculate the radial component of velocity at the outlet: Assuming the width of the impeller channel at the outlet is *w*,\)v_{r2} = \(. We need to assume a value for *w* to proceed. If we assume *w*=0.02 m:\)v_{r2} = \(5. Calculate the tangential component of velocity at the outlet:\)v_{u2} = u_2 - v_{r2} = 22.9 - 3.82 - 8.2 \(6. Calculate the theoretical head:\)H = = $* Problem 2: A centrifugal pump is pumping water at 20°C. The inlet pressure is 120 kPa, the inlet velocity is 2 m/s, and the vapor pressure of water at 20°C is 2.33 kPa. Calculate the NPSHA.
    • Solution:
      1. The density of water is approximately 1000 kg/m^3. 2.\(NPSHA = \frac{p_{inlet}}{\rho g} + \frac{v_{inlet}^2}{2g} - \frac{p_{vapor}}{\rho g} = \frac{120000}{1000 \cdot 9.81} + \frac{2^2}{2 \cdot 9.81} - \frac{2330}{1000 \cdot 9.81} \approx 12.23 + 0.20 - 0.24 = 12.19 \text{ m}\)[Image generation failed for: Illustration of cavitation occurring near the impeller inlet, showing vapor bubbles forming and collapsing.]

1.3 Applications and Limitations

1.3.1 Theoretical Introduction

Hydrodynamic pumps find widespread use in various applications due to their ability to deliver high flow rates and handle variable demand. One of the most common applications is in water supply systems, where centrifugal pumps are used to transport water from reservoirs or wells to homes and businesses. These pumps can efficiently handle the fluctuating demand for water throughout the day.

Another significant application area is in HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning) systems. Centrifugal pumps are used to circulate chilled water or hot water through the system, providing heating or cooling to buildings. The ability of these pumps to handle variable flow rates is crucial in HVAC systems, as the demand for heating or cooling changes depending on the time of day and the weather conditions.

Hydrodynamic pumps are also used in slurry transport, where they are used to move mixtures of solids and liquids. These pumps are designed to be robust and resistant to abrasion, allowing them to handle the abrasive nature of slurries. Examples of slurry transport applications include mining operations and wastewater treatment plants.

However, hydrodynamic pumps have limitations. One of the primary limitations is their relatively low-pressure capability compared to positive displacement pumps. Hydrodynamic pumps are generally not suitable for applications requiring very high pressures. They are also sensitive to fluid viscosity; as viscosity increases, the pump’s performance (flow rate, head, and efficiency) decreases.

Centrifugal and axial flow pumps have different performance characteristics that make them suitable for different applications. Centrifugal pumps are well-suited for applications requiring moderate flow rates and moderate heads, while axial flow pumps are best for applications requiring high flow rates and low heads.

Pump selection involves considering several factors, including the required flow rate, head, NPSH requirements, and fluid properties. It is also important to consider the operating environment and the expected lifespan of the pump.

Pump affinity laws are a set of relationships that describe how the performance of a pump changes with changes in pump speed and impeller diameter. These laws are useful for predicting the performance of a pump under different operating conditions.

From a first-principles perspective, dimensional analysis can be used to understand the relationships between the various parameters that affect pump performance. Fluid rheology, the study of the flow and deformation of matter, is important for understanding how fluid properties affect pump performance, particularly in the case of non-Newtonian fluids.

1.3.2 Mathematical Derivations

The pump affinity laws relate flow rate (\(Q\)), head (\(H\)), and power (\(\mathcal{P}\)) to pump speed (\(N\)) and impeller diameter (\(D\)). These laws are based on the assumption that the pumps are geometrically similar, meaning that they have the same shape and proportions.

The affinity laws are as follows:

  • Flow Rate:\(\frac{Q_1}{Q_2} = \frac{N_1}{N_2} \left( \frac{D_1}{D_2} \right)^3\)* Head:\(\frac{H_1}{H_2} = \left( \frac{N_1}{N_2} \right)^2 \left( \frac{D_1}{D_2} \right)^2\)* Power:\(\frac{\mathcal{P}_1}{\mathcal{P}_2} = \left( \frac{N_1}{N_2} \right)^3 \left( \frac{D_1}{D_2} \right)^5\)Specific speed (\(N_s\)) is a dimensionless parameter used to classify pumps based on their geometry and operating characteristics. It is defined as:\(N_s = \frac{N \sqrt{Q}}{H^{3/4}}\)where N is pump speed (RPM), Q is flow rate (GPM), and H is head (feet). Note that this equation is in US customary units. Converting to metric units requires careful attention to units.

[Image generation failed for: System curve and pump curve plotted on the same graph, showing the operating point.]

1.3.3 Mirror Problems

  • Problem 1: A centrifugal pump delivers 100 GPM at a head of 50 feet when operating at 1750 RPM. If the pump speed is increased to 2000 RPM, what will be the new flow rate and head? Assume impeller diameter is constant.

    • Solution:
      1. Using the affinity laws: \(\frac{Q_1}{Q_2} = \frac{N_1}{N_2} \left( \frac{D_1}{D_2} \right)^3\). Since D1 = D2, we have\(\frac{Q_1}{Q_2} = \frac{N_1}{N_2}\). Thus\(Q_2 = Q_1 * \frac{N_2}{N_1} = 100 * \frac{2000}{1750} = 114.3 \text{ GPM}\). \(\frac{H_1}{H_2} = \left( \frac{N_1}{N_2} \right)^2 \left( \frac{D_1}{D_2} \right)^2\). Since D1 = D2, we have\(\frac{H_1}{H_2} = \left( \frac{N_1}{N_2} \right)^2\). Thus\(H_2 = H_1 * \left( \frac{N_2}{N_1} \right)^2 = 50 * \left( \frac{2000}{1750} \right)^2 = 64.5 \text{ feet}\).

  • Problem 2: A pump is required to deliver 500 GPM at a head of 100 feet. The pump operates at 1750 RPM. Calculate the specific speed of the pump and suggest a suitable pump type (centrifugal or axial).

    • Solution:
      1. Calculate the specific speed:\(N_s = \frac{N \sqrt{Q}}{H^{3/4}} = \frac{1750 \cdot \sqrt{500}}{100^{3/4}} \approx \frac{1750 * 22.36}{31.62} = 1237\).
      2. Based on the specific speed, a centrifugal pump would be a suitable choice, as the specific speed falls within the typical range for centrifugal pumps. Axial pumps have higher specific speeds.

2. Hydrostatic or Positive Displacement Pumps

This type of pump ejects a fixed quantity of fluid per revolution of the pump shaft. As a result, pump output flow, neglecting the small internal leakage, is constant and not dependent on system pressure. This makes them particularly well suited for fluid power systems. However, positive displacement pumps must be protected against overpressure if the resistance to flow becomes very large or infinite. This can happen if a valve is completely closed and there is no physical place for the fluid to go. The reason for this is that a positive displacement pump continues to eject fluid (even though it has no place to go), causing an extremely rapid buildup in pressure as the fluid is compressed. A pressure relief valve is used to protect the pump against stored for system use.

Positive displacement pumps can be classified by the type of motion of internal elements. The motion may be either rotary or reciprocating. Although these pumps come in a wide variety of different designs, there are essentially three basic types:

Introduction to Positive Displacement Pumps

Positive displacement pumps are a cornerstone of fluid power systems, providing a reliable and consistent flow of hydraulic fluid. To fully appreciate their function, it’s essential to understand the fundamental difference between positive displacement and non-positive displacement (or dynamic) pumps. Dynamic pumps, such as centrifugal pumps commonly used for water transfer, operate by imparting kinetic energy to the fluid. This kinetic energy is then converted into pressure. A key characteristic of dynamic pumps is that their flow rate is highly dependent on the system pressure. As the pressure against which the pump is working increases, the flow rate decreases significantly. Think of a garden hose with a nozzle; when you partially block the nozzle, the pressure increases, but the flow reduces.

In contrast, positive displacement pumps operate on a completely different principle. They work by repeatedly trapping a fixed, discrete volume of fluid within an internal chamber and then mechanically forcing (displacing) that volume into the discharge line. With each cycle or rotation of the pump, the same defined volume of fluid is transferred, regardless of the downstream pressure (within the pump’s operational limits, of course). This “positive” and consistent displacement of fluid is the defining characteristic that sets them apart from dynamic pumps.

This inherent property makes positive displacement pumps exceptionally well-suited for use in hydraulic systems, where a consistent and predictable flow rate is often paramount. For example, hydraulic actuators, such as cylinders and motors, rely on a stable flow rate to control their speed and position with precision. However, this characteristic of constant flow also introduces a critical safety concern: the need for overpressure protection. Because the pump will continue to try and displace fluid even when a valve is closed or a line is blocked, system pressure can rapidly increase to dangerous levels if no safety mechanism is in place.

The theoretical flow rate (\(Q_{th}\)) of a positive displacement pump is directly linked to two key parameters: its displacement volume (\(V_d\)) and its rotational speed (\(N\)). The displacement volume represents the amount of fluid that the pump displaces with each complete revolution of its internal mechanism.

[Image generation failed for: Schematic representation of a generic positive displacement pump showing inlet and outlet ports, direction of flow, and displacement volume Vd.]

Mathematically, the theoretical flow rate can be expressed with the following equation:\(Q_{th} = V_d \cdot N\)Where:

\(V_d\)is the pump displacement (the volume displaced per revolution, typically measured in units like m³/rev or cm³/rev). \(N\)is the rotational speed of the pump shaft (typically measured in revolutions per second (rev/s) or revolutions per minute (RPM)). *\(Q_{th}\)is the theoretical flow rate (typically measured in units like m³/s or L/min).

It’s important to note that the actual flow rate (\(Q_{act}\)) delivered by a real-world pump will always be less than this theoretical value. This discrepancy arises due to internal leakages within the pump. Fluid can slip past the internal clearances between moving parts, reducing the amount of fluid effectively delivered to the outlet. This leakage is quantified by the volumetric efficiency (\(\eta_v\)), which is a dimensionless parameter that represents the ratio of the actual flow rate to the theoretical flow rate:\(\eta_v = \frac{Q_{act}}{Q_{th}}\)Therefore, the actual flow rate can be more accurately expressed as:\(Q_{act} = \eta_v \cdot Q_{th} = \eta_v \cdot V_d \cdot N\)The volumetric losses that reduce the actual flow rate are primarily caused by fluid slipping past internal clearances. These clearances exist between gears in gear pumps, vanes in vane pumps, and pistons in piston pumps, as well as between these components and the pump housing. The magnitude of these losses is influenced by several factors, including the viscosity of the hydraulic fluid, the operating pressure, and the precision of the pump’s manufacturing tolerances. Higher pressures tend to exacerbate leakage, as the fluid is forced through smaller gaps. Likewise, a decrease in fluid viscosity (due to increased temperature, for example) can increase leakage.

The power required to drive the pump (\(\mathcal{P}_{in}\)) is directly related to the system pressure (\(p\)) and the actual flow rate (\(Q_{act}\)). The higher the pressure and flow rate, the more power the pump requires to operate. However, not all of the input power is converted into useful hydraulic power delivered to the system; there are inevitably losses due to friction and other inefficiencies. The overall efficiency (\(\eta_{overall}\)) accounts for all of these losses. The hydraulic power delivered to the system,\(\mathcal{P}_{hyd}\), is given by\(\mathcal{P}_{hyd} = p \cdot Q_{act}\)The overall efficiency is then defined as the ratio of the hydraulic power output to the mechanical power input:\(\eta_{overall} = \frac{\mathcal{P}_{hyd}}{\mathcal{P}_{in}}\)From this definition, we can derive an expression for the required input power to the pump:\(\mathcal{P}_{in} = \frac{p \cdot Q_{act}}{\eta_{overall}}\)The overall efficiency encompasses several contributing factors, including volumetric losses (leakage, as discussed above), mechanical losses (friction in bearings, gears, and other moving parts within the pump), and hydraulic losses (pressure drops across internal components, such as valves and orifices). These losses convert some of the input power into heat, which must be dissipated to prevent overheating of the hydraulic system.

Mirror Problems:

Problem 1: A positive displacement pump has a displacement of\(V_d\)= 35 cm³/rev and operates at a rotational speed of\(N\)= 1800 RPM. The volumetric efficiency is\(\eta_v\)= 92%. Calculate the theoretical and actual flow rates.

Solution:

First, convert the units to be consistent (cm³/rev to m³/rev, RPM to rev/s):\(V_d = 35 \frac{cm^3}{rev} * (\frac{1 m}{100 cm})^3 = 35 \times 10^{-6} \frac{m^3}{rev}\)\(N = 1800 \frac{rev}{min} * \frac{1 min}{60 s} = 30 \frac{rev}{s}\)Calculate the theoretical flow rate:\(Q_{th} = V_d \cdot N = (35 \times 10^{-6} \frac{m^3}{rev}) \cdot (30 \frac{rev}{s}) = 1.05 \times 10^{-3} \frac{m^3}{s}\)Convert to L/min:\(Q_{th} = 1.05 \times 10^{-3} \frac{m^3}{s} * \frac{1000 L}{1 m^3} * \frac{60 s}{1 min} = 63 \frac{L}{min}\)Calculate the actual flow rate:\(Q_{act} = \eta_v \cdot Q_{th} = 0.92 \cdot 63 \frac{L}{min} = 57.96 \frac{L}{min}\)Problem 2: A positive displacement pump has a displacement of\(V_d\)= 45 cm³/rev and operates at a rotational speed of\(N\)= 2000 RPM. The system pressure is\(p\)= 20 MPa, and the overall efficiency is\(\eta_{overall}\)= 75%. Calculate the required input power.

Solution:

First, convert the units to be consistent:\(V_d = 45 \frac{cm^3}{rev} * (\frac{1 m}{100 cm})^3 = 45 \times 10^{-6} \frac{m^3}{rev}\)\(N = 2000 \frac{rev}{min} * \frac{1 min}{60 s} = \frac{100}{3} \frac{rev}{s}\)Calculate the theoretical flow rate:\(Q_{th} = V_d \cdot N = (45 \times 10^{-6} \frac{m^3}{rev}) \cdot (\frac{100}{3} \frac{rev}{s}) = 1.5 \times 10^{-3} \frac{m^3}{s}\)Assuming a volumetric efficiency of, say, 90%:\(Q_{act} = \eta_v \cdot Q_{th} = 0.90 \cdot 1.5 \times 10^{-3} \frac{m^3}{s} = 1.35 \times 10^{-3} \frac{m^3}{s}\)Calculate the required input power:\(\mathcal{P}_{in} = \frac{p \cdot Q_{act}}{\eta_{overall}} = \frac{(20 \times 10^6 Pa) \cdot (1.35 \times 10^{-3} \frac{m^3}{s})}{0.75} = \frac{27000 W}{0.75} = 36000 W = 36 kW\)Problem 3: A hydraulic system has an actual flow rate of\(Q_{act}\)= 25 L/min, operates at a system pressure of\(p\)= 15 MPa, and the pump requires an input power of\(\mathcal{P}_{in}\)= 10 kW. Calculate the overall efficiency.

Solution:

First, convert the units to be consistent:\(Q_{act} = 25 \frac{L}{min} * \frac{1 m^3}{1000 L} * \frac{1 min}{60 s} = \frac{25}{60000} \frac{m^3}{s} = 4.167 \times 10^{-4} \frac{m^3}{s}\)\(\mathcal{P}_{in} = 10 kW = 10000 W\)Calculate the overall efficiency:\(\eta_{overall} = \frac{p \cdot Q_{act}}{\mathcal{P}_{in}} = \frac{(15 \times 10^6 Pa) \cdot (4.167 \times 10^{-4} \frac{m^3}{s})}{10000 W} = \frac{6250.5 W}{10000 W} = 0.625 = 62.5\%\)Problem 4: A positive displacement pump has a theoretical flow rate of\(Q_{th}\)= 40 L/min and an actual flow rate of\(Q_{act}\)= 35 L/min. If the pump operates at a rotational speed of\(N\)= 1200 RPM, calculate the volumetric efficiency (\(\eta_v\)) and the pump displacement (\(V_d\)).

Solution:

First, convert the units to be consistent:\(Q_{th} = 40 \frac{L}{min} * \frac{1 m^3}{1000 L} * \frac{1 min}{60 s} = \frac{40}{60000} \frac{m^3}{s} = 6.667 \times 10^{-4} \frac{m^3}{s}\)\(Q_{act} = 35 \frac{L}{min} * \frac{1 m^3}{1000 L} * \frac{1 min}{60 s} = \frac{35}{60000} \frac{m^3}{s} = 5.833 \times 10^{-4} \frac{m^3}{s}\)\(N = 1200 \frac{rev}{min} * \frac{1 min}{60 s} = 20 \frac{rev}{s}\)Calculate the volumetric efficiency:\(\eta_v = \frac{Q_{act}}{Q_{th}} = \frac{5.833 \times 10^{-4} \frac{m^3}{s}}{6.667 \times 10^{-4} \frac{m^3}{s}} = 0.875 = 87.5\%\)Calculate the pump displacement:\(V_d = \frac{Q_{th}}{N} = \frac{6.667 \times 10^{-4} \frac{m^3}{s}}{20 \frac{rev}{s}} = 3.3335 \times 10^{-5} \frac{m^3}{rev}\)Convert to cm³/rev:\(V_d = 3.3335 \times 10^{-5} \frac{m^3}{rev} * (\frac{100 cm}{1 m})^3 = 33.335 \frac{cm^3}{rev}\)### Overpressure Protection and Relief Valves

Positive displacement pumps, due to their inherent design, are prone to creating dangerous overpressure situations within hydraulic systems. As previously discussed, these pumps continuously deliver a fixed volume of fluid with each cycle or revolution, regardless of the resistance encountered downstream. This characteristic, while beneficial for maintaining consistent flow rates, can lead to severe problems if the flow is obstructed.

Imagine a scenario where a valve in the hydraulic system is suddenly closed, or a hydraulic cylinder reaches the end of its stroke. In such cases, the pump will continue to attempt to deliver fluid into a now-blocked line. Because the fluid is relatively incompressible, the pressure within the system will rise extremely rapidly. If this pressure is allowed to increase unchecked, it can quickly exceed the design limits of the pump and other components in the hydraulic system, leading to catastrophic failure. This failure can range from burst hoses and cracked fittings to damaged cylinders and even pump rupture, posing significant safety risks to personnel and equipment.

To prevent these dangerous overpressure situations, a pressure relief valve (PRV) is an absolutely essential safety device in any hydraulic system that uses a positive displacement pump. The PRV functions as a pressure-limiting valve, automatically diverting excess fluid away from the system when the pressure reaches a predetermined threshold. This diverted fluid is typically routed back to the hydraulic fluid reservoir or, in some designs, back to the inlet side of the pump.

The basic principle of a PRV is relatively simple. It consists of a spring-loaded valve (typically a poppet or spool valve) that is held closed by the force of a spring. The pressure of the hydraulic fluid acts on the valve element, opposing the spring force. As long as the system pressure remains below the valve’s setpoint, the spring force is sufficient to keep the valve closed, and the fluid flows normally through the system. However, when the system pressure exceeds the setpoint (the cracking pressure), the fluid pressure overcomes the spring force, causing the valve to open. This opening allows a portion of the fluid to flow through the relief valve and back to the reservoir, thereby limiting the pressure in the system. The valve will modulate its opening to maintain a safe pressure level.

[Image generation failed for: Cross-sectional view of a direct-acting pressure relief valve, showing the poppet, spring, adjustment screw, inlet port, and outlet port. Label the cracking pressure.]

There are several different types of PRVs available, each with its own advantages and disadvantages. Two common types are direct-acting PRVs and pilot-operated PRVs. Direct-acting PRVs are the simplest in design. The system pressure acts directly on the valve poppet, and when the pressure exceeds the spring force, the poppet lifts, allowing fluid to flow. Direct-acting valves are known for their fast response time, making them suitable for applications where rapid pressure surges are likely. However, they tend to exhibit some pressure overshoot as they open, meaning that the pressure may briefly exceed the setpoint before the valve fully opens and stabilizes the pressure.

Pilot-operated PRVs, on the other hand, use a two-stage design. A small, direct-acting pilot valve senses the system pressure. When the pressure reaches the setpoint, the pilot valve opens, which then allows the main valve to open. This pilot operation provides more precise pressure control and reduces the amount of pressure overshoot compared to direct-acting valves. However, pilot-operated valves are generally slower to respond to rapid pressure changes due to the two-stage operation.

Several key parameters define the performance characteristics of a PRV:

  • Cracking Pressure (\(p_{cracking}\)): This is the pressure at which the relief valve begins to open and allow fluid to flow. Below this pressure, the valve remains fully closed.
  • Full Flow Pressure (\(p_{full flow}\)): This is the pressure at which the valve is fully open and capable of passing its rated flow capacity. The pressure typically increases slightly above the cracking pressure to reach the full flow condition.
  • Reseat Pressure: This is the pressure at which the relief valve closes after relieving pressure. It is usually slightly lower than the cracking pressure to prevent the valve from oscillating open and closed.

The cracking pressure is directly related to the spring force (\(F_{spring}\)) and the effective area of the valve poppet (\(A_{poppet}\)) on which the pressure acts. The relationship is given by:\(p_{cracking} = \frac{F_{spring}}{A_{poppet}}\)This equation highlights that increasing the spring force or decreasing the poppet area will increase the cracking pressure, and vice versa.

The flow rate through the relief valve (\(Q_{valve}\)) is related to the pressure difference across the valve (\(\Delta p = p - p_{cracking}\)), the valve’s discharge coefficient (\(C_d\)), the poppet area (\(A_{poppet}\)), and the density of the hydraulic fluid (\(\rho\)). A simplified model, based on Bernoulli’s equation and incorporating the discharge coefficient to account for real-world effects, is given by:\(Q_{valve} = C_d A_{poppet} \sqrt{\frac{2 \Delta p}{\rho}}\)It’s crucial to recognize that this equation is a significant simplification and does not capture all of the complexities of fluid flow through a real-world valve. Factors such as fluid viscosity, turbulence, and the specific geometry of the valve can all influence the actual flow rate. The discharge coefficient (\(C_d\)) is an empirically determined value that attempts to account for these deviations from the ideal model. In practice, valve manufacturers provide flow curves that relate the flow rate through the valve to the pressure drop across it, offering a more accurate representation of the valve’s performance.

[Image generation failed for: Hydraulic circuit diagram showing a positive displacement pump, a pressure relief valve, and a directional control valve connected to a cylinder. Show flow path when PRV is activated.]

Mirror Problems:

Problem 1: A pressure relief valve has a spring force of\(F_{spring}\)= 120 N and a poppet area of\(A_{poppet}\)= 50 mm². Calculate the cracking pressure.

Solution:

Convert units to be consistent:\(A_{poppet} = 50 mm^2 * (\frac{1 m}{1000 mm})^2 = 50 \times 10^{-6} m^2\)Calculate the cracking pressure:\(p_{cracking} = \frac{F_{spring}}{A_{poppet}} = \frac{120 N}{50 \times 10^{-6} m^2} = 2.4 \times 10^6 Pa = 2.4 MPa\)Problem 2: A direct-acting relief valve has a spring with a stiffness of\(k_{spring}\)= 8 N/mm. The valve poppet has an area of\(A_{poppet}\)= 70 mm². The valve is set to crack at\(p_{cracking}\)= 9 MPa. What is the initial compression of the spring? If the system pressure rises to 11 MPa, how much further will the poppet move?

Solution:

First, convert the poppet area to\(m^2\):\(A_{poppet} = 70 mm^2 * (\frac{1 m}{1000 mm})^2 = 70 \times 10^{-6} m^2\)Calculate the initial spring force required to crack the valve:\(F_{spring} = p_{cracking} * A_{poppet} = 9 \times 10^6 Pa * 70 \times 10^{-6} m^2 = 630 N\)Calculate the initial spring compression:\(x_{spring} = \frac{F_{spring}}{k_{spring}} = \frac{630 N}{8 N/mm} = 78.75 mm\)When the pressure rises to 11 MPa, the additional force on the poppet is:\(\Delta F = (11 \times 10^6 Pa - 9 \times 10^6 Pa) * 70 \times 10^{-6} m^2 = 2 \times 10^6 Pa * 70 \times 10^{-6} m^2 = 140 N\)The additional movement of the poppet is:\(\Delta x = \frac{\Delta F}{k_{spring}} = \frac{140 N}{8 N/mm} = 17.5 mm\)—

Okay, I understand. The feedback indicates that the previous expansion was too heavy on mathematical derivations and not focused enough on providing a broad overview suitable for a textbook introduction to gear pumps. I will remove the detailed mathematical sections and instead focus on elaborating on the working principles, characteristics, applications, advantages, and disadvantages of each gear pump type.

  1. Gear pumps (fixed displacement only by geometrical necessity):

    Gear pumps are a class of positive displacement pumps characterized by their simplicity and reliability. They are commonly used in hydraulic systems to provide a constant flow rate for a given speed, regardless of the system pressure. The “fixed displacement” nature of these pumps arises from their fundamental operating principle: a fixed volume of fluid is mechanically transferred from the inlet to the outlet with each revolution of the gears or screws. This is unlike dynamic pumps such as centrifugal pumps, where the flow rate changes significantly with pressure. Gear pumps are valued for their ability to provide consistent flow, ease of maintenance, and relatively low cost compared to other types of positive displacement pumps. However, they are also known for their higher noise levels and are typically limited to lower pressure applications.

    [Image generation failed for: Generic cross-section of a positive displacement pump showing the inlet and outlet ports, and a representative displacement mechanism.]

    Common applications for gear pumps include hydraulic power units, lubrication systems, and fluid transfer in various industrial processes. Their robust design makes them suitable for environments where reliability and ease of service are paramount. While gear pumps are not ideal for applications requiring very high pressures or extremely quiet operation, their combination of simplicity, affordability, and consistent flow makes them a popular choice in many fluid power systems.

    1. External gear pumps:

      External gear pumps are among the simplest and most widely used types of gear pumps. They consist of two meshing gears rotating within a close-fitting housing. As the gears rotate, fluid is drawn into the pump through the inlet port, trapped between the gear teeth and the housing, and then carried around to the outlet port. The meshing of the gears at the outlet forces the fluid out, creating a continuous flow.

      [Image generation failed for: Detailed cross-section of an external gear pump showing the two gears, inlet port, outlet port, and housing. Indicate the direction of rotation of each gear and the flow path of the fluid.]

      External gear pumps are known for their compact size, simple construction, and ability to deliver moderate flow rates at moderate pressures. They are commonly used in automotive oil pumps, hydraulic power packs, and various industrial applications where cost-effectiveness and reliability are important. However, external gear pumps can be relatively noisy due to the trapping of fluid between the meshing gears (known as “trapped volume”), which can lead to pressure pulsations. Furthermore, they are not ideally suited for handling fluids with abrasive particles, as these can wear down the gears and reduce pump efficiency.

    2. Internal gear pumps:

      Internal gear pumps offer improved performance characteristics compared to external gear pumps, particularly in terms of noise and efficiency. There are primarily two common designs: the gerotor and the crescent internal gear pump. These pumps utilize an internal gear (rotor) and an external gear (idler) that mesh together within a housing.

      In a gerotor pump, the inner gear has one fewer tooth than the outer gear. This creates a series of crescent-shaped chambers that expand and contract as the gears rotate, drawing fluid into the pump and then forcing it out. The crescent internal gear pump utilizes a crescent-shaped spacer to separate the inlet and outlet ports and prevent backflow.

      [Image generation failed for: Detailed cross-section of an internal gear pump (Gerotor type) showing the inner and outer gears, the crescent-shaped spacer (if applicable), inlet port, and outlet port. Indicate the direction of rotation of each gear and the flow path of the fluid.]

      Internal gear pumps are valued for their quieter operation and higher efficiency compared to external gear pumps. This is largely due to the reduced “trapped volume” and smoother fluid flow within the pump. They are commonly used in applications where low noise is critical, such as elevators, hydraulic lifts, and power steering systems. Internal gear pumps are typically more expensive and have a more complex construction than external gear pumps, but their improved performance often justifies the increased cost.

    3. Lobe pumps:

      Lobe pumps are similar in principle to external gear pumps, but instead of gears, they use rotating lobes to move fluid. The lobes do not make contact with each other; instead, timing gears located outside the pumping chamber synchronize their rotation. As the lobes rotate, they create expanding cavities on the inlet side of the pump, drawing fluid in. The fluid is then carried around the outside of the lobes and forced out through the outlet port.

      [Image generation failed for: Detailed cross-section of a lobe pump showing the lobes, timing gears, inlet port, and outlet port. Indicate the direction of rotation of the lobes and the flow path of the fluid.]

      Lobe pumps are particularly well-suited for handling fluids containing solids, such as slurries, pastes, and food products. Their gentle pumping action minimizes shear and damage to the fluid, making them ideal for applications where product integrity is important. Lobe pumps are commonly used in the food processing, pharmaceutical, and chemical industries. However, lobe pumps typically have lower pressure capabilities and larger physical dimensions compared to other types of gear pumps.

    4. Screw pumps:

      Screw pumps use one or more screws to move fluid axially along the pump. The screws rotate within a close-fitting housing, creating sealed chambers that progress from the inlet to the outlet. As the screws turn, the fluid is trapped within these chambers and pushed forward, generating a continuous flow.

      [Image generation failed for: Detailed cross-section of a screw pump showing the screws, inlet port, and outlet port. Indicate the direction of rotation of the screws and the flow path of the fluid.]

      Screw pumps are known for their ability to deliver high flow rates at relatively low noise levels. They are also capable of handling viscous fluids and can provide smooth, pulsation-free flow. Screw pumps are commonly used in oil and gas pipelines, fuel transfer systems, and hydraulic power units. However, screw pumps have complex manufacturing requirements and are sensitive to contamination. The close clearances between the screws and the housing make them susceptible to damage from abrasive particles.

2. Vane Pumps

Vane pumps are a type of positive-displacement pump that utilizes a rotating rotor with sliding vanes to create chambers that trap and transfer fluid. As the rotor turns, the vanes extend and retract, driven by centrifugal force and/or pressure from the pumped fluid, maintaining contact with the pump housing (also called a cam ring or stator). This creates expanding volumes on the inlet side, drawing fluid in, and contracting volumes on the outlet side, forcing fluid out. This cyclic process delivers a relatively constant flow rate for a given speed. Positive displacement means that for each revolution, a fixed amount of fluid is displaced, offering high volumetric efficiency. Vane pumps are known for their quiet operation, moderate pressure capabilities, and ability to handle thin fluids. They find applications in various industries, including automotive power steering, hydraulic systems for machine tools, and fuel pumps. However, they are generally less suitable for abrasive fluids due to the wear on the vanes and housing. Compared to gear pumps, vane pumps generally offer quieter operation and better efficiency, while compared to piston pumps, they are simpler in design and more compact, but typically operate at lower pressures.

[Image generation failed for: Cutaway view of a generic vane pump showing rotor, vanes, cam ring (stator), inlet port, outlet port, and direction of rotation.]

The theoretical flow rate (\(Q_{th}\)) of a vane pump can be derived based on its geometry and rotational speed, assuming perfect sealing between the vanes and the housing. Let’s define:

\(D_r\): Rotor diameter \(h_v\): Vane height \(w_c\): Chamber width (average width of the chamber formed between two adjacent vanes) \(N_v\): Number of vanes \(e\): Eccentricity (for unbalanced pumps; the distance between the rotor center and the cam ring center) \(\omega\): Rotational speed (in radians per second)

For an unbalanced vane pump, the volume displaced per vane passage is proportional to the area created by the eccentricity and the vane height (\(e \cdot h_v\)). The total volume displaced per revolution is then the number of vanes times this area times the chamber width (\(N_v \cdot e \cdot h_v \cdot w_c\)) multiplied by two because fluid is sucked in and pushed out. Thus, the theoretical volumetric displacement is\(V_d = 2 \cdot N_v \cdot e \cdot h_v \cdot w_c\)The volumetric flow rate is the volume displaced per revolution times the revolutions per unit time. Since\(\omega\)is in radians per second, we need to divide by\(2\pi\)to get revolutions per second, so\(Q_{th} = V_d \cdot \frac{\omega}{2 \pi} = \frac{N_v \cdot e \cdot h_v \cdot w_c \cdot \omega}{\pi}\)The hydraulic power (\(\mathcal{P}_{hyd}\)) output of the pump is the product of the outlet pressure (\(p\)) and the actual flow rate (\(Q_{out}\)):\(\mathcal{P}_{hyd} = p \cdot Q_{out}\)Note that\(Q_{out}\)will always be less than\(Q_{th}\)due to internal leakages.

[Image generation failed for: Schematic representation of the pumping action: Several stages with the rotor rotating, showing the volume between vanes increasing at the inlet and decreasing at the outlet.]

Example Problem 1: Calculate the theoretical flow rate of an unbalanced vane pump.

Given: * Rotor diameter (\(D_r\)) = 100 mm = 0.1 m * Vane height (\(h_v\)) = 20 mm = 0.02 m * Chamber width (\(w_c\)) = 10 mm = 0.01 m * Number of vanes (\(N_v\)) = 8 * Eccentricity (\(e\)) = 5 mm = 0.005 m * Rotational speed (\(\omega\)) = 1500 RPM =\(1500 \cdot \frac{2\pi}{60}\)rad/s =\(50\pi\)rad/s

  1. Calculate the theoretical flow rate:$Q_{th} = = = 0.004 m^3/s\(2. Convert to L/min:\)Q_{th} = 0.004 = 240 L/min$Example Problem 2: Determine the required rotational speed to achieve a target flow rate.

Given: * Target flow rate (\(Q_{target}\)) = 50 L/min =\(50/60000\)m³/s =\(1/1200\)m³/s * Rotor diameter (\(D_r\)) = 80 mm = 0.08 m * Vane height (\(h_v\)) = 18 mm = 0.018 m * Chamber width (\(w_c\)) = 8 mm = 0.008 m * Number of vanes (\(N_v\)) = 9 * Eccentricity (\(e\)) = 6 mm = 0.006 m

  1. Rearrange the flow rate equation to solve for\(\omega\):\(Q_{th} = \frac{N_v \cdot e \cdot h_v \cdot w_c \cdot \omega}{\pi}\)\(\omega = \frac{Q_{th} \cdot \pi}{N_v \cdot e \cdot h_v \cdot w_c} = \frac{\frac{1}{1200} \cdot \pi}{9 \cdot 0.006 \cdot 0.018 \cdot 0.008} \approx 335.4\)rad/s
  2. Convert to RPM:\(\omega = 335.4 \frac{rad}{s} \cdot \frac{60 s}{1 min} \cdot \frac{1}{2\pi} \frac{rev}{rad} \approx 3202 RPM\)## 2.a. Unbalanced Vane Pumps (Fixed or Variable Displacement)

Unbalanced vane pumps feature a rotor offset within the pump housing (cam ring), creating a crescent-shaped pumping chamber. This eccentricity is the key to their operation. The rotor’s rotation causes the vanes to extend and retract within the cam ring, creating expanding and contracting volumes as described above. A fixed displacement unbalanced vane pump has a cam ring with a permanently fixed eccentricity, resulting in a constant volume of fluid being displaced per revolution. A variable displacement unbalanced vane pump, on the other hand, incorporates a mechanism to adjust the eccentricity of the cam ring. This is typically achieved by mounting the cam ring on a pivoting mechanism, allowing its position relative to the rotor to be altered. By changing the eccentricity, the volume of fluid displaced per revolution can be varied, enabling control over the pump’s flow rate. The trade-off is the significant radial load on the rotor shaft. This is because the pressure at the outlet port is high, while pressure at the inlet port is low, and these pressures act unevenly on the rotor, causing wear and tear.

[Image generation failed for: Cross-sectional view of a fixed displacement unbalanced vane pump, highlighting the eccentricity and the resulting pressure distribution (with arrows indicating pressure magnitude).]

The side load force (\(F_{side}\)) on the rotor can be approximated by considering the pressure distribution around the rotor. A simplified approach assumes a linear pressure gradient from the inlet pressure (\(p_{inlet} \approx 0\)) to the outlet pressure (\(p\)). The average pressure acting on one side of the rotor is then\(p/2\). This average pressure acts over an area that is approximately the product of the rotor diameter (\(D_r\)) and the eccentricity (\(e\)). Therefore, the side load force can be approximated as:\(F_{side} \approx \frac{1}{2} \cdot p \cdot D_r \cdot e\)The theoretical torque (\(T_{th}\)) required to drive the pump can be derived from the hydraulic power and rotational speed. Since\(\mathcal{P}_{hyd} = p \cdot Q_{out}\), and assuming\(Q_{out} \approx Q_{th} = V_d \cdot \omega / (2 \pi)\), the power can be expressed as:\(\mathcal{P}_{hyd} = p \cdot V_d \cdot \frac{\omega}{2 \pi}\)Also, the input mechanical power to the pump is equal to the product of torque and rotational speed,\(\mathcal{P}_{in} = T_{th} \cdot \omega\)(in ideal conditions, where\(\mathcal{P}_{in} = \mathcal{P}_{hyd}\)). Therefore,\(T_{th} \cdot \omega = p \cdot V_d \cdot \frac{\omega}{2 \pi}\)\(T_{th} = \frac{V_d \cdot p}{2 \pi}\)[Image generation failed for: Schematic of a variable displacement unbalanced vane pump with an adjustable cam ring, showing the mechanism for changing eccentricity.]

Example Problem 1: Calculate the side load force on the rotor of an unbalanced vane pump.

Given: * Eccentricity (\(e\)) = 6 mm = 0.006 m * Rotor diameter (\(D_r\)) = 100 mm = 0.1 m * Outlet pressure (\(p\)) = 15 MPa =\(15 \times 10^6\)Pa

  1. Calculate the side load force:\(F_{side} \approx \frac{1}{2} \cdot p \cdot D_r \cdot e = \frac{1}{2} \cdot 15 \times 10^6 \cdot 0.1 \cdot 0.006 = 4500 N\)Example Problem 2: Determine the required input torque to drive an unbalanced vane pump.

Given: * Volumetric displacement (\(V_d\)) = 30 cm³/rev =\(30 \times 10^{-6}\)m³/rev * Outlet pressure (\(p\)) = 12 MPa =\(12 \times 10^6\)Pa

  1. Calculate the theoretical torque:\(T_{th} = \frac{V_d \cdot p}{2 \pi} = \frac{30 \times 10^{-6} \cdot 12 \times 10^6}{2 \pi} \approx 57.3 Nm\)## 2.b. Balanced Vane Pumps (Fixed Displacement)

Balanced vane pumps are designed to mitigate the radial forces inherent in unbalanced vane pumps. This is achieved by employing an elliptical or oval-shaped cam ring. This unique shape creates two inlet ports and two outlet ports diametrically opposed to each other. As the rotor rotates, fluid is drawn in through both inlet ports simultaneously, and expelled through both outlet ports simultaneously. The symmetrical arrangement of these ports results in a balanced pressure distribution around the rotor. The radial forces generated by the pressure at one outlet port are effectively cancelled out by the equal and opposite forces generated at the other outlet port. Similarly, the forces at the inlet ports are also balanced. This balancing of forces significantly reduces the load on the rotor bearings, enabling the pump to operate at higher pressures and with improved reliability compared to unbalanced designs. Because the cam ring shape is fixed to achieve this balance, balanced vane pumps are typically fixed displacement.

[Image generation failed for: Cross-sectional view of a balanced vane pump, highlighting the elliptical cam ring, the two inlet ports, and the two outlet ports. Indicate the direction of rotation.]

Deriving the theoretical flow rate (\(Q_{th}\)) for a balanced vane pump requires considering the geometry of the elliptical cam ring. Let\(a\)and\(b\)represent the semi-major and semi-minor axes of the ellipse, respectively. The eccentricity in this case can be related to\(a\)and\(b\), but the overall pumping action effectively occurs twice per revolution.

A simplified approximation for the theoretical flow rate is:\(Q_{th} \approx \frac{2 \cdot N_v \cdot (a-b) \cdot h_v \cdot w_c \cdot \omega}{\pi}\)Note that the\(a-b\)term replaces the eccentricity term\(e\)of the unbalanced pump, and there is also a factor of 2 multiplying the front of the expression.

The reduction in side loads can be understood qualitatively. In an unbalanced pump, the net radial force is approximately proportional to the eccentricity (\(e\)). In a balanced pump, due to the symmetry of the elliptical cam ring and the dual inlet/outlet ports, the radial forces generated on opposite sides of the rotor tend to cancel each other out. While a full derivation of the residual side load is complex, we can represent the qualitative effect as:\(F_{side, balanced} \approx k \cdot F_{side, unbalanced}\)Where\(k << 1\), representing a significant reduction in side load.

[Image generation failed for: Diagram illustrating the pressure distribution in a balanced vane pump, showing how the radial forces are balanced.]

Example Problem 1: Calculate the theoretical flow rate of a balanced vane pump.

Given: * Rotor diameter (\(D_r\)) = 80 mm * Vane height (\(h_v\)) = 20 mm = 0.02 m * Chamber width (\(w_c\)) = 10 mm = 0.01 m * Number of vanes (\(N_v\)) = 10 * Rotational speed (\(\omega\)) = 2000 RPM =\(2000 \cdot \frac{2\pi}{60}\)rad/s\(\approx 209.4\)rad/s * Semi-major axis (\(a\)) = 50 mm = 0.05 m * Semi-minor axis (\(b\)) = 45 mm = 0.045 m

  1. Calculate the theoretical flow rate:$Q_{th} = m^3/s\(2. Convert to L/min:\)Q_{th} = 0.00133 L/min$Example Problem 2: Calculate the theoretical torque required to drive a balanced vane pump

Given: * Volumetric displacement (\(V_d\)) = 40 cm³/rev =\(40 \times 10^{-6}\)m³/rev * Outlet pressure (\(p\)) = 10 MPa =\(10 \times 10^6\)Pa

  1. Calculate the theoretical torque:\(T_{th} = \frac{V_d \cdot p}{2 \pi} = \frac{40 \times 10^{-6} \cdot 10 \times 10^6}{2 \pi} \approx 63.7 Nm\)—

  2. Piston Pumps (Fixed or Variable Displacement)

Piston pumps represent a fundamental class of positive displacement pumps widely employed in hydraulic systems. Their operation relies on the reciprocating motion of a piston within a cylinder to displace fluid. The underlying principle involves converting rotary motion, typically provided by an electric motor or engine, into linear reciprocating motion of the piston. As the piston retracts, it creates a vacuum (partial pressure reduction) within the cylinder, drawing fluid in through an inlet valve. Conversely, as the piston advances, it forces the fluid out through an outlet valve. This cyclical process generates a continuous flow of fluid.

The distinction between fixed and variable displacement piston pumps lies in their stroke length. In a fixed displacement pump, the stroke length, and therefore the volume of fluid displaced per cycle, remains constant. Consequently, the flow rate is directly proportional to the pump’s rotational speed. In contrast, a variable displacement pump allows for adjustment of the stroke length, enabling control over the flow rate even at a constant pump speed. This adjustability is achieved through mechanisms that alter the piston’s range of motion within the cylinder. These mechanisms will be discussed in detail when axial and radial piston pumps are introduced.

The pumping action directly relates to pressure generation through Pascal’s Law, which states that pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted equally in all directions. The force exerted by the piston on the fluid creates pressure. This pressure is then transmitted throughout the hydraulic system, enabling the operation of actuators and other hydraulic components.

Piston pumps are favored for applications demanding high pressure capabilities due to their robust design and ability to generate substantial forces. However, they inherently produce pulsating flow due to the intermittent nature of the piston’s movement. This pulsation can be mitigated through the use of multiple pistons, accumulators, or other flow-smoothing devices.

[Image generation failed for: Cross-sectional view of a single piston pump]

To understand the theoretical performance of piston pumps, consider a simplified mathematical analysis. Let’s derive key equations starting from first principles.

  • Pump Displacement Volume (Single Piston):

The displacement volume (\(V_D\)) for a single piston is the volume swept by the piston as it moves through its stroke. This volume is determined by the piston’s cross-sectional area and the stroke length. If D represents the piston diameter, then the area, A, of the piston face will be\(\pi \cdot (\frac{D}{2})^2 = \frac{\pi D^2}{4}\). If s represents the stroke length, then the volume displaced per stroke will be the product of the piston face area and the stroke length:\(V_D = A \cdot s\)\(V_D = \frac{\pi D^2}{4} s\)* Total Displacement Volume (Multi-Piston):

For a pump with n pistons, the total displacement volume (\(V_{DT}\)) is simply the sum of the individual displacement volumes:\(V_{DT} = n \cdot V_D\)Substituting the expression for\(V_D\):\(V_{DT} = n \cdot \frac{\pi D^2}{4} s\)* Theoretical Flow Rate:

The theoretical flow rate (\(Q_T\)) represents the ideal volume of fluid delivered by the pump per unit time, assuming no internal leakage. It is calculated by multiplying the total displacement volume by the pump speed (N), typically expressed in revolutions per minute (RPM). To ensure unit consistency, it is necessary to convert from revolutions per minute into a useful engineering unit.\(Q_T = V_{DT} \cdot N\)Assuming N is in RPM and we want the flow rate in liters per minute (L/min) and all linear units (\(D\)and\(s\)) are in millimeters (mm):\(Q_T = n \cdot \frac{\pi D^2}{4} s \cdot N \frac{rev}{min} \cdot \frac{1 L}{10^6 mm^3}\)\(Q_T = n \cdot \frac{\pi D^2 s N}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)* Output Hydraulic Power:

The output hydraulic power (P) of the pump is the rate at which it delivers energy to the hydraulic system. It is the product of the pressure (p) and the flow rate (Q).\(P = p \cdot Q\)To obtain power in Watts, if the pressure is given in Pascals (Pa) and flow rate is in cubic meters per second (\(m^3/s\)):\(P = p \cdot Q\)Watts (W)

The input mechanical power needed to drive the pump must overcome losses due to friction and inefficiencies. This input power is related to the pump’s torque (T) and speed (N):\(P_{in} = T \cdot \omega = T \cdot 2\pi N\)Where:\(\omega\)is the angular velocity in radians per second.

Mirror Problems:

  • Problem 1 (Single Piston): A single-piston pump has a piston diameter (D) of 50 mm, a stroke length (s) of 30 mm, and operates at a speed (N) of 1200 RPM. Calculate the theoretical flow rate.

Solution:\(Q_T = \frac{\pi D^2 s N}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = \frac{\pi (50 mm)^2 (30 mm) (1200 RPM)}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = 35.34 \frac{L}{min}\)* Problem 2 (Multi-Piston - Axial): An axial piston pump has 7 pistons (n = 7), a piston diameter (D) of 25 mm, a stroke length (s) of 15 mm, and operates at a speed (N) of 1800 RPM and an operating pressure (p) of 20 MPa. Calculate the theoretical flow rate and output hydraulic power.

Solution:\(Q_T = n \cdot \frac{\pi D^2 s N}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = 7 \cdot \frac{\pi (25 mm)^2 (15 mm) (1800 RPM)}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = 30.9 \frac{L}{min}\)First, convert the flow rate to\(m^3/s\):\(Q_T = 30.9 \frac{L}{min} \cdot \frac{1 m^3}{1000 L} \cdot \frac{1 min}{60 s}\)\(Q_T = 5.15 \times 10^{-4} \frac{m^3}{s}\)Then calculate the hydraulic power, and convert to kilowatts (kW):\(P = p \cdot Q\)\(P = (20 \times 10^6 Pa) \cdot (5.15 \times 10^{-4} \frac{m^3}{s})\)\(P = 10300 W = 10.3 kW\)* Problem 3 (Variable Displacement): A variable displacement pump has 9 pistons (n = 9), a piston diameter (D) of 20 mm, a maximum stroke length (\(s_{max}\)) of 10 mm, and operates at a speed (N) of 2000 RPM and operating pressure of p = 15 MPa. The stroke length can vary from 20% to 100% of\(s_{max}\). Calculate the flow rate and power output at minimum and maximum stroke lengths.

Solution:

Minimum Stroke Length:\(s_{min} = 0.20 \cdot s_{max} = 0.20 \cdot 10 mm = 2 mm\)Maximum Stroke Length:\(s_{max} = 10 mm\)Flow Rate at Minimum Stroke:\(Q_{T,min} = n \cdot \frac{\pi D^2 s_{min} N}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_{T,min} = 9 \cdot \frac{\pi (20 mm)^2 (2 mm) (2000 RPM)}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_{T,min} = 1.13 \frac{L}{min}\)Flow Rate at Maximum Stroke:\(Q_{T,max} = n \cdot \frac{\pi D^2 s_{max} N}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_{T,max} = 9 \cdot \frac{\pi (20 mm)^2 (10 mm) (2000 RPM)}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_{T,max} = 5.65 \frac{L}{min}\)Hydraulic Power at Minimum Stroke:\(Q_{T,min} = 1.13 \frac{L}{min} \cdot \frac{1 m^3}{1000 L} \cdot \frac{1 min}{60 s} = 1.88 \times 10^{-5} \frac{m^3}{s}\)\(P_{min} = p \cdot Q_{T,min} = (15 \times 10^6 Pa) (1.88 \times 10^{-5} \frac{m^3}{s}) = 282 W\)Hydraulic Power at Maximum Stroke:\(Q_{T,max} = 5.65 \frac{L}{min} \cdot \frac{1 m^3}{1000 L} \cdot \frac{1 min}{60 s} = 9.42 \times 10^{-5} \frac{m^3}{s}\)\(P_{max} = p \cdot Q_{T,max} = (15 \times 10^6 Pa) (9.42 \times 10^{-5} \frac{m^3}{s}) = 1413 W\)* Problem 4 (Piston Force Balance): Calculate the force on a single piston of diameter (D) of 40 mm subjected to hydraulic fluid at a pressure (p) of 30 MPa.

The force (\(F_p\)) exerted on a piston by hydraulic fluid is determined by the product of the pressure and the piston’s cross-sectional area:$F_p = p A = p $\(F_p = (30 \times 10^6 N/m^2) \cdot \frac{\pi (0.04 m)^2}{4} = 37699 N\)a. Axial Design

Axial piston pumps represent a specific configuration of piston pumps where the pistons are arranged parallel to the pump’s drive shaft (axially). The pumping action is achieved through the interaction of these pistons with a rotating swash plate or a bent axis. These designs are capable of operating at relatively high speeds, but require complex and precise manufacturing techniques.

[Image generation failed for: Cross-section of an axial piston pump]

The swash plate is an inclined disc that rotates with the drive shaft. The pistons are connected to the swash plate through connecting rods or slippers. As the swash plate rotates, the pistons are forced to reciprocate within their cylinders. The stroke length of the pistons is determined by the angle of the swash plate. By varying this angle, the displacement, and therefore the flow rate, of the pump can be adjusted. This adjustability makes axial piston pumps well-suited for variable displacement applications.

The bent-axis design is another common axial piston pump configuration. In this design, the cylinder block is tilted at an angle relative to the drive shaft. The pistons are arranged axially within the cylinder block and are connected to a flange on the drive shaft. As the drive shaft rotates, the pistons are forced to reciprocate within their cylinders. The stroke length is determined by the angle between the cylinder block and the drive shaft.

Let’s derive the relationship between the swash plate angle, stroke length, and other parameters in a swash plate type pump:

If we define the swash plate angle as\(\alpha\), and the swash plate diameter at the point of contact with the pistons as d, we can calculate the stroke length (s) as:\(s = d \cdot \tan(\alpha)\)However, in some axial pump designs, the stroke is more directly proportional to the sine of the angle. It is important to verify the design before applying this formula.

If we now wish to re-derive the theoretical flow rate, the new flow rate is now parameterized by the diameter of the swashplate, the angle of the swashplate, and the number of pistons in the pump:\(Q_T = n \cdot \frac{\pi D^2}{4} \cdot (d \cdot \tan(\alpha)) \cdot N \frac{rev}{min} \cdot \frac{1 L}{10^6 mm^3}\)\(Q_T = \frac{n \pi D^2 d \tan(\alpha) N}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)Mirror Problems:

  • Problem 1: An axial piston pump has a swash plate diameter (d) of 100 mm, a swash plate angle (alpha) of 15 degrees, 7 pistons (n = 7), piston diameter (D) of 20mm, and operates at a speed (N) of 2000 RPM. Calculate the theoretical flow rate.\(Q_T = \frac{n \pi D^2 d \tan(\alpha) N}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = \frac{7 \cdot \pi \cdot (20 mm)^2 \cdot (100 mm) \cdot \tan(15) \cdot 2000}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = \frac{7 \cdot \pi \cdot 400 \cdot 100 \cdot 0.268 \cdot 2000}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = 11.85 \frac{L}{min}\)* Problem 2: An axial piston pump is to be designed to achieve a flow rate (Q_T) of 100 L/min. The design is constrained to have a swash plate diameter (d) of 120 mm, 9 pistons (n = 9), piston diameter (D) of 22 mm, and a pump speed (N) of 2500 RPM. Calculate the required swash plate angle (alpha).\(Q_T = \frac{n \pi D^2 d \tan(\alpha) N}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(\tan(\alpha) = \frac{Q_T \cdot 4 \times 10^6}{n \pi D^2 d N}\)\(\tan(\alpha) = \frac{(100 \frac{L}{min}) \cdot 4 \times 10^6}{9 \cdot \pi \cdot (22 mm)^2 \cdot (120 mm) \cdot (2500 RPM)} = 0.97\)\(\alpha = atan(0.97) = 44.2^\circ\)* Problem 3: An axial piston pump with the following specifications: number of pistons (n=7), piston diameter (D = 25 mm), swash plate diameter (d = 125 mm), and pump speed (N = 1500 RPM). If the swash plate is set to an angle of (alpha = 15 degrees), determine the theoretical flow rate of the pump.\(Q_T = \frac{n \pi D^2 d \tan(\alpha) N}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = \frac{7 \cdot \pi \cdot (25 mm)^2 \cdot (125 mm) \cdot \tan(15) \cdot 1500}{4 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min} = 24.18 \frac{L}{min}\)b. Radial Design

Radial piston pumps represent another primary type of piston pump, distinguished by the radial arrangement of the pistons. In these pumps, the pistons are positioned radially around a central cylinder block. The pumping action is generated by the reciprocating movement of these pistons within their respective cylinders. Typically, radial piston pumps employ a rotating cam ring to drive the pistons.

[Image generation failed for: Cross-section of a radial piston pump]

The cam ring is an eccentric ring that rotates around the cylinder block. The pistons are connected to the cam ring through rollers or slippers. As the cam ring rotates, the pistons are forced to reciprocate within their cylinders. The stroke length of the pistons is determined by the eccentricity between the cam ring and the cylinder block. Variable displacement is achieved by altering this eccentricity, allowing for adjustments in the pump’s flow rate.

Let’s derive the relationship between the eccentricity, stroke length, and cam ring radius:

The stroke length s is approximately twice the eccentricity e:\(s \approx 2e\). This approximation holds true when the eccentricity is small compared to the cam ring radius (\(R\)). A more exact equation can be difficult to derive and may rely on lookup tables from FEA analysis of a complex mechanism.

The theoretical flow rate (\(Q_T\)) can be expressed as:\(Q_T = n \cdot \frac{\pi D^2}{4} \cdot (2e) \cdot N \frac{rev}{min} \cdot \frac{1 L}{10^6 mm^3}\)\(Q_T = \frac{n \pi D^2 e N}{2 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)Mirror Problems:

  • Problem 1: A radial piston pump has an eccentricity (e) of 10 mm, 5 pistons (n = 5), piston diameter (D) of 20 mm, and operates at a speed (N) of 1000 RPM. Calculate the theoretical flow rate.\(Q_T = \frac{n \pi D^2 e N}{2 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = \frac{5 \cdot \pi \cdot (20 mm)^2 \cdot (10 mm) \cdot (1000 RPM)}{2 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = \frac{5 \cdot \pi \cdot 400 \cdot 10 \cdot 1000}{2 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = 31.42 \frac{L}{min}\)* Problem 2: A radial piston pump is to be designed to deliver a flow rate (Q_T) of 80 L/min. The pump design has 7 pistons (n = 7), a piston diameter (D) of 25 mm, and operates at a speed (N) of 2000 RPM. Calculate the required eccentricity (e).\(Q_T = \frac{n \pi D^2 e N}{2 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(e = \frac{Q_T \cdot 2 \times 10^6}{n \pi D^2 N}\)\(e = \frac{(80 \frac{L}{min}) \cdot 2 \times 10^6}{7 \cdot \pi \cdot (25 mm)^2 \cdot (2000 RPM)} = 9.71 mm\)* Problem 3: A radial piston pump with 5 pistons. The pistons have a diameter of 20mm. The pump operates with an eccentricity of 8mm and a rotational speed of 1200 rpm. Calculate the theoretical flow rate.\(Q_T = \frac{n \pi D^2 e N}{2 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min}\)\(Q_T = \frac{5 \cdot \pi \cdot (20 mm)^2 \cdot (8 mm) \cdot (1200 RPM)}{2 \times 10^6} \frac{L}{min} = 30.16 \frac{L}{min}\)Vane Pumps

Vane pumps are another type of positive displacement pump commonly used in hydraulic systems. Their working principle involves a rotor with radial slots, vanes that slide in these slots, and a cam ring. As the rotor rotates inside the cam ring, the vanes are forced to extend and retract within the slots. The volume between the rotor, vanes, and cam ring changes, creating suction and discharge.

As the rotor rotates, centrifugal force, and sometimes springs, keep the vanes extended against the inner surface of the cam ring. During one portion of the rotation, the volume between adjacent vanes increases, creating a partial vacuum that draws fluid into the pump (suction). During another portion of the rotation, the volume decreases, forcing fluid out of the pump (discharge).

Vane pumps are often favored for their relatively quiet operation. However, they generally have lower pressure capabilities compared to piston pumps.

[Image generation failed for: Cross-sectional view of a vane pump]

Let us derive the equations for calculating theoretical flow rate. Note, the derivation of these equations are not trivial, and many textbooks take liberties with the assumptions to simplify the math.

Assumptions:

  • The cam ring is perfectly circular, but offset from the rotor center
  • The vanes extend to contact the cam ring at all times (they have negligible thickness).
  • The fluid is incompressible.

Given these assumptions, we can estimate the theoretical flow rate:

First, we must estimate the displacement volume (\(V_D\)) for a vane pump:\(V_D = \pi \cdot n \cdot w \cdot L (R + r)\)Where: * R = Cam Ring Radius * r = Rotor Radius * w = Vane Width * L = Vane Length * n = number of vanes

Theoretical flow rate (\(Q_T\)):\(Q_T = V_D \cdot N\)Mirror Problems:

  • Problem 1: A vane pump has a cam ring radius (R) of 75 mm, a rotor radius (r) of 50 mm, a vane width (w) of 10 mm, a vane length (L) of 35 mm, number of vanes (n) of 8, and operates at a speed (N) of 1200 RPM. Calculate the theoretical flow rate.\(V_D = \pi \cdot n \cdot w \cdot L (R - r)\)\(V_D = \pi \cdot 8 \cdot 10 mm \cdot 35 mm \cdot (75mm - 50mm)\)\(V_D = 219911.49 mm^3\)\(Q_T = V_D \cdot N \frac{rev}{min} \cdot \frac{1 L}{10^6 mm^3}\)\(Q_T = 219911.49 mm^3 \cdot 1200 \frac{rev}{min} \cdot \frac{1 L}{10^6 mm^3}\)\(Q_T = 263.89 \frac{L}{min}\)* Problem 2: A vane pump needs to deliver a flow rate (Q_T) of 50 L/min. The pump has a cam ring radius (R) of 80 mm, a rotor radius (r) of 60 mm, a vane width (w) of 8 mm, a vane length (L) of 40 mm, and operates at a speed (N) of 1500 RPM. Calculate the required number of vanes (n).\(Q_T = \pi \cdot n \cdot w \cdot L (R - r) \cdot N \frac{rev}{min} \cdot \frac{1 L}{10^6 mm^3}\)\(n = \frac{Q_T \cdot 10^6}{\pi \cdot w \cdot L (R-r) N}\)\(n = \frac{50 \frac{L}{min} \cdot 10^6}{\pi \cdot (8 mm) \cdot (40 mm) \cdot (80 mm - 60 mm) \cdot (1500)}\)\(n = \frac{50 \times 10^6}{3015928.94} = 16.58\)Since n must be an integer, use 17 vanes.

  • Problem 3: Calculate the theoretical flow rate of a vane pump using the following parameters: number of vanes (7), vane length (30 mm), rotor radius (65 mm), cam ring radius (85 mm), pump speed (1350 rpm).\(Q_T = \pi \cdot n \cdot w \cdot L (R - r) \cdot N \frac{rev}{min} \cdot \frac{1 L}{10^6 mm^3}\)Assume w = 10mm\(Q_T = \pi \cdot 7 \cdot 10 mm \cdot 30 mm \cdot (85mm - 65mm) \cdot 1350 \frac{rev}{min} \cdot \frac{1 L}{10^6 mm^3}\)\(Q_T = 59.40 \frac{L}{min}\)Unbalanced Vane Pumps

Unbalanced vane pumps are characterized by a single cam lobe. This design results in a radial force on the rotor due to the uneven pressure distribution. Robust bearings are necessary to withstand this force and maintain the pump’s operational integrity.

[Image generation failed for: Cross-sectional view of an unbalanced vane pump]

Mirror Problems:

  • Problem 1: An unbalanced vane pump has a cam ring radius defined by\(R = a + b\cos(2\theta)\), where a = 100 mm and b = 20 mm are constants and\(\theta\)is the angle. The rotor radius (r) is 75 mm, the vane width (w) is 8 mm, the vane length (L) is 30 mm, the number of vanes (n) is 10, and the pump speed (N) is 1000 RPM. The average outlet pressure (P) is 5 MPa. Estimate the theoretical flow rate and the maximum radial force on the rotor.

This problem requires more advanced calculations and potentially numerical methods. A simplified approach for estimating the radial force would involve: 1. Calculating the pressure distribution around the cam ring based on the cam ring profile. 2. Integrating the pressure forces to find the net radial force. 3. The theoretical flow rate can be calculated using the equations from the general vane pump section, but it’s important to note that the cam ring shape is no longer circular, so the formula using (R - r) is an approximation.

Balanced Vane Pumps
